docs.lead_paragraph: A picture caption with the continuation of a front-page article on Monday about the financial strain on New Orleans because of a boom in births to indigent immigrants there misidentified a doctor at a clinic. He is Dr. Robert Post, medical director of Daughters of Charity Services -- not Dr. Mark Peters, chief executive of East Jefferson General Hospital in Metairie.
docs.abstract: Correction of photo caption with Dec 11 article about births to indigent illegal immigrants in New Orleans since Hurricane Katrina; doctor at clinic is Robert Post

docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, students will examine the content of popular energy drinks by conducting research about stimulants and sweeteners. They then create posters outlining how these compounds affect consumers.
docs.snippet: In this lesson, students will examine the content of popular energy drinks by conducting research about stimulants and sweeteners. They then create posters outlining how these compounds affect consumers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Here’s an unpleasant figure for a man to ponder: 10 percent of all children conceived in the context of a marriage (or a less formal heterosexual pairing) have been fathered by someone from outside the couple. “Dad” has been cuckolded. Or so many biologists and anthropologists have been saying for decades.

docs.lead_paragraph: If the mere thought of opening a bag of spinach, using an airplane toilet or touching raw hamburger leaves you petrified, consider the E. coli-detecting wipe developed by Dapeng Li, Margaret Frey and Antje Baeumner at Cornell University.
